sentences.sentence: A psychiatrist and two social workers write about stigma and discrimination.
Also: Presidential papers; gas stoves; transgender courage; writing and thinking.To the Editor:Re “I Edited Mental Illness Out of My College Applications.
I'm Not Alone,” by Emi Nietfeld (Opinion guest essay, nytimes.com, Dec. 31):I commend Ms. Nietfeld for bravely sharing her story, and The New York Times for highlighting this issue.

It's time for us all to speak out and to battle the stigma and discrimination faced by young people struggling with mental health disorders.None of us want to send our children to a place that does not fully recognize and address their needs.

Our institutions of higher learning should understand that a young person's riskiest period for mental health disorders is under the age of 24, and they should provide an environment that is consistent, nurturing and accepting.Everyone's mental health, but especially that of our children, suffered from the isolation and uncertainty of the last few years.

This collective experience encouraged people to become more open about their challenges, but now, as we begin to emerge from the pandemic and feel relieved to be getting back to “normal,” that can also mean returning to pre-Covid attitudes about mental health.I encourage colleges and universities to be our allies in holding onto the gains we've made, and help us continue to take strides forward, so that each student's school feels like home away from home.Harold S. KoplewiczNew YorkThe writer, a child and adolescent psychiatrist, is the founding president and medical director of the Child Mind Institute.To the Editor:Pressuring students to scrub their past of any signs of mental illness not only further stigmatizes these conditions but also makes it more likely that students won't reach out when they're in need of help.
This is a dangerous and irresponsible precedent that has already led to too many tragedies.People living with mental health challenges are already some of the most marginalized and isolated.

Instead of treating them as liabilities, universities must step up to support students with a mental illness as they would for students with any other disability.This includes not only developing more compassionate admissions policies but also making it easier for students who need professional clinical care to take the time they need to recover without worrying about whether they'll lose their spot.If colleges are to make meaningful headway on addressing mental health, they need to own up to the fact that a student shouldn't have to be “a pristine survivor who was not marred by trauma,” in the words of the essay, and instead promote a culture in which students feel safe to be authentic advocates for themselves.By creating a more holistic culture that sees and recognizes students as human beings, schools will be better equipped to properly provide students with resources to help them succeed.Anna GuimaraesJulie WolfsonNew YorkThe writers are licensed social workers who lead Fountain House's College Re-Entry program.A President's Papers: 'Mistakes Happen'To the Editor:Few executives do their own paperwork.
Everyone has assistants, and the most powerful have many assistants, who have their own assistants.All presidents have left it to assistants to sort the paperwork at the end of their administration.
Mistakes happen.

It is probable that every president has taken home or misplaced documents, some of them sensitive.It is likely that in those cases, when the documents were discovered they were quietly returned to the National Archives, and no fuss was made, until now.An enterprising reporter could surely uncover these incidents and demonstrate how completely common and trivial they are.Albert SavoyHuntington, N.Y.Health Risks From Gas StovesTo the Editor:Re “Lawmakers' Debate Over Gas Stoves and Health Hazards Reaches a Rolling Boil” (news article, Jan. 12):I wish Republicans in Congress would have as much outrage about gun violence and a 6-year-old boy shooting his teacher as they express about one federal commissioner's comment, based on valid scientific evidence, that his agency might take some regulatory action to protect the public from adverse health effects of gas stoves.A child shooting his teacher while in class merits outrage.
Possible health risks from stoves merit further study.

A suggestion that regulatory action on stoves might be taken years in the future merits a shrug.Daniel FinkBeverly Hills, Calif.To the Editor:It will likely be decades before we fully switch from natural gas as fuel for home heating and stoves.

The recent concerns about indoor air pollution caused by gas stoves may be valid, as homes become better sealed for energy efficiency.The solution for this problem may be relatively simple: Instead of banning gas stoves, just alter the codes so that all new construction and kitchen renovations are required to have an outside vented exhaust system.
This will exhaust the stove fumes outside, as currently occurs with gas water heaters and furnaces.

Banning gas stoves seems like an excessive step for a simple problem.David J. MelvinChester, N.J.Transgender CourageTo the Editor:Re “I Chose to Compete as My True, Trans Self,” by Iszac Henig (Opinion guest essay, Jan. 7):I'm a baby boomer, born in 1950, and I've never known a transgender person.

But of course I have, or at least some who desperately wished they could acknowledge their true selves but didn't dare to.I still struggle with understanding, but Mr. Henig's riveting piece helped me grasp how difficult or impossible it is to live as the wrong gender, the enormous work it takes to transition and most of all the courage to do it.Things have changed in so many ways since 1950, many for the good.

Thank you, Mr. Henig, for illuminating one of them.George HagerWashingtonWriting and ThinkingTo the Editor:Re “Fourth Grader or Chatbot?” (The Upshot, Jan. 4):To learn to write is to learn to think.During my 15 years in a high school English department, one of our standard assignments was: “Choose a passage from tonight's reading assignment that is interesting, significant and meaningful, and in one page of writing, explain why it is interesting, significant and meaningful.”The beauty of this is that it gives teenagers great freedom, while putting the burden on them to develop insights, recognize meanings, make connections.

Putting these into the best words is vital ᅳ but only a close second to having the best thoughts.My teenagers were simultaneously joyous and freaked out by this assignment; nobody was telling them what to write about!Wails I would hear (and it was always music to my ears to hear my teenagers say what they were feeling) in connection with, say, “Macbeth” or “1984” might be, “Mr.
V., I never know what to write about!” or “Mr.
V., nothing in this book is interesting!” or “Mr.

V., whaddaya mean by 'meaningful'?”No chatbot will ever help kids with this most necessary and enduring of writing tasks: to have an idea entirely on one's own and to make it clear to others.Marc VincentiPalo Alto, Calif.This article appeared in print on page A21.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

MelvinChester, N.J.Transgender CourageTo the Editor:Re “I Chose to Compete as My True, Trans Self,” by Iszac Henig (Opinion guest essay, Jan. 7):I’m a baby boomer, born in 1950, and I’ve never known a transgender person.
